abstract.title: Summary:
abstract.p: Comminuted proximal phalangeal fractures of the thumb are inherently unstable injuries requiring surgical fixation to provide stability and restore function. Current fixation methods include plate and screw fixation, which is associated with stiffness (in 64% of cases), extensor lag, and hardware complications requiring further operations. Moreover, intramedullary screws carry the risk of cartilage damage and fracture displacement during insertion. These modalities requiring extensive soft tissue dissection correlate with poor functional outcomes due to fibrosis and vascular disruption. A simplified surgical technique was presented through a case of open comminuted thumb proximal phalangeal fracture managed with antegrade intramedullary Kirschner wire transfixation of both the metacarpophalangeal joint (MCPJ) and interphalangeal joint. This approach acknowledges the biomechanical reality that thumb function primarily relies on carpometacarpal joint mobility, with the MCPJ contributing substantially less to functional opposition, making temporary MCPJ immobilization well tolerated. Extended stabilization is critical, as evidenced by a documented case report showing loss of reduction between 9 and 14 weeks postoperatively, even with a rigid fixation method. The technique presented offers several advantages: minimal soft tissue disruption preserving vascularity essential for healing, no pin tract infection despite nonburied wire fixation, simplified removal without additional anesthesia, and economic benefits through reduced operating time and the absence of expensive implants. Radiographic union was achieved by 16 weeks, with good functional recovery and no complications. This technique represents a valuable balance between stability requirements and soft tissue preservation, particularly in open injuries where extensive surgical approaches may be contraindicated.

sec.title: Takeaways
sec.p: Question: What are the efficacy and advantages of the antegrade intramedullary Kirschner wire (K-wire) technique with joint transfixation for managing open comminuted thumb proximal phalangeal fractures?

Findings: A minimally invasive approach was demonstrated using a single antegrade K-wire transfixing both the interphalangeal and metacarpophalangeal joints for 12 weeks in an open comminuted thumb proximal phalangeal fracture, resulting in complete union with good functional recovery.

Meaning: Antegrade K-wire transfixation provides extended stability with minimal soft tissue disruption for comminuted thumb proximal phalangeal fractures, with temporary metacarpophalangeal joint immobilization well tolerated due to the thumb’s unique biomechanical properties.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: A 60-year-old man presented with a wounded left thumb following a collision. Radiographs showed an acute, severely comminuted fracture of the proximal phalanx with apex volar angulation (Fig. 1A). Examination revealed superficial laceration over the thumb, indicating an open fracture, with tenderness, diffuse swelling, and limited range of motion (ROM), whereas neurovascular examination was normal. Surgery was performed under general anesthesia with a tourniquet inflated to 230 mm Hg. Under fluoroscopy, a singular 1.6-mm Kirschner wire (K-wire) was inserted percutaneously from the metacarpal base without penetrating the metacarpophalangeal joint (MCPJ). To reduce the displacement of comminuted fragments, traction was applied, and pressure was exerted on the proximal phalangeal shaft and base from the palmar, dorsal, radial, or ulnar aspects. Upon achieving reduction, the K-wire was advanced through the MCPJ into the comminuted medullary canal of the proximal phalanx. Subsequently, the K-wire was further introduced through the interphalangeal joint (IPJ) into the distal phalanx, transfixing both MCPJ and IPJ in extension. The patient was followed up at 4-week intervals with meticulous pin site care and splinting. At 12 weeks, with partial union visible radiographically, the K-wire was removed in the clinic under aseptic conditions without requiring additional anesthesia (Fig. 1B). Early active mobilization of both joints was initiated with a structured hand therapy protocol. By 16 weeks, radiographic union was evident with good recovery of ROM (Figs. 1C, D). (See Video [online], which demonstrates the functional recovery of thumb ROM including opposition, reposition, flexion, and extension at 16 weeks postoperatively.) No complications such as delayed union, malunion, nonunion, loss of reduction, or pin tract infection occurred during the postoperative follow-up. The patient expressed satisfaction with the clinical outcomes.

sec.title: DISCUSSION WITH LITERATURE REVIEW
sec.p: In the upper extremities, phalangeal fractures are the second most prevalent injury, with proximal phalangeal fractures eliciting more substantial deformity than middle or distal counterparts.1 Comminuted fractures in this region are particularly unstable,2 often resulting in unsatisfactory outcomes due to their inherent instability.3

Consequently, surgical fixation is typically imperative to impart additional stability.2 There is a scarcity of literature regarding addressing comminuted thumb proximal phalangeal fractures, without consensus on optimal fixation methods. Meticulous techniques have been advocated,1–4 including K-wire; intramedullary screw; plate and screw; bone graft; and external fixation methods, such as the Joshi external stabilization system5 and traction splints6 to maintain sterility of the hematoma at the fracture site. The proximal phalanx experiences significant biomechanical forces during common activities, with studies demonstrating forces approaching 25 N during jar opening. In thumb proximal phalangeal fractures, the flexor and extensor tendons impart longitudinal compression forces, shortening the phalanx and extending the distal fragment, creating deforming forces requiring fixation.2 These multiplanar forces necessitate robust yet minimally invasive fixation.

Trauma-induced tissue injury primarily causes stiffness regardless of the fixation method, whereas extensive dissection for rigid fixation can exacerbate this process.4 Soft tissue injuries correlate with poor outcomes due to fibrosis and scarring from vascular disruption.3 Complications of intramedullary screws include cartilage damage and displacement during insertion, whereas plate fixation is associated with stiffness, extensor lag, infection, nonunion, and hardware failure. Plates may impede tendon gliding, necessitating hardware removal and tenolysis.2 Previous studies reported that 64% of phalangeal fractures developed stiffness after plate fixation, with 20% requiring additional surgery.4 Our minimally invasive antegrade intramedullary pinning technique addresses these concerns.

K-wire fixation facilitates indirect bone healing, reducing adhesion-related stiffness between hardware and the extensor mechanism, yielding excellent results when early ROM is ensured.2 Although transfixing joints for 12 weeks may cause complications, recent studies show that a single transarticular wire provides similar stability to crossed wires in unstable proximal phalangeal fractures.4 Despite longer immobilization compared with plating, K-wire fixation demonstrates comparable total active motion and return-to-work timing.7

The thumb is uniquely suited for this approach, as the MCPJ is most amenable to fixation strategies that may temporarily restrict MCPJ mobility, making MCPJ motion less crucial for thumb function.1 Thumb motion predominantly relies on carpometacarpal joint mobility, with the MCPJ contributing substantially less to functional opposition.8 The saddle-shaped carpometacarpal joint’s capacity for multiplanar motion makes it the critical joint for thumb functionality, explaining why temporary metacarpophalangeal immobilization is well tolerated. This anatomical peculiarity renders the thumb particularly suitable for our technique, as evidenced by good functional recovery in our patient despite the 12-week period of joint transfixation. The necessity for prolonged stability is evidenced by a case where, even with rigid fixation and autografting, reduction was lost between 9 and 14 weeks postoperatively.1

Our technique provides extended stability while avoiding soft tissue disruption. The antegrade approach offers superior control of wire placement9 while preserving vascularity essential for healing, particularly in comminuted fragments that may have a tenuous blood supply. Although radiographic healing with K-wire fixation often lags behind clinical healing, with fracture gaps potentially visible for up to 4 months,2 this indirect healing process produces good functional outcomes. Furthermore, a 0% infection rate with percutaneous K-wire fixation for up to 12 weeks was reported, whereas nonburied wires improve efficiency without compromising safety.10 This technique requires minimal specialized equipment, making it particularly advantageous in resource-limited settings.

This antegrade intramedullary pinning technique with MCPJ and IPJ transfixation for comminuted thumb proximal phalangeal fractures provides a minimally invasive approach with satisfactory reduction and functional recovery. The technique balances stability and soft tissue preservation, addressing a fundamental challenge in hand fracture management. The absence of infection despite extended fixation, preservation of thumb function, and technical simplicity position this method as a valuable addition to the surgical armamentarium for managing these challenging fractures, especially in open injuries where wound healing concerns may preclude more extensive approaches.

The methodology aligns with core treatment goals—restoration of function while limiting complications.4 By employing a single K-wire rather than multiple wires or plates, the surgeon minimizes the foreign body burden while maintaining adequate stability. Economic advantages include reduced operating time, absence of expensive implants, and potentially shorter hospital stays.

Limitations are acknowledged. First, complications may occur with K-wire, such as infection, migration, wire breakage, loss of reduction, malunion, and nonunion, despite stability enhanced by transfixation of both the MCPJ and IPJ and larger diameter K-wires, prompting frequent radiographic monitoring. Second, evidence derived from a single case report was rather limited, emphasizing the necessity of comparative studies for validation in the future.
